metadata.title: GPS-Based Bus Stop Prediction Using Machine  Learning: A Data-Driven Approach for Smart  Urban Transit
metadata.description:
Abstract - Urbanization and increased reliance on public transport warrants efficient bus stop identifying. This research utilizedmachine learning and DBSCAN clustering to predict bus stops from GPS traces (GPX files) identifying true stops versus 
temporary stops. Key steps included preforming preprocessing of GPX data (latitude, longitude, speed, timestamp), detecting 
zero-speed periods, and clustering stop points based on frequency and confidence. The model for predicting bus stops scores GPX files for support and frequency of stops that occur in a particular GPX file. The resulting system tested against OpenStreetMap (OSM) data and manual surveys accurately identified bus stopsin a variety of urban settings, including urban settings with density and complexity. Utilization of interactive maps and statistical visualizations supported better interpretation of identified bus stops, and the overall approach is easily scalable for transit agencies to better plan transit in their context and 
hopefully improve passenger experience across cities and contexts.
keywords: Urbanization, Public Transport, Bus Stop Prediction, GPS Traces, GPX Files, Machine Learning, DBSCAN Clustering, Preprocessing, Zero-Speed Detection, Clustering, Stop Frequency, Confidence Scoring, OpenStreetMap, Manual Survey, Urban Mobility, Interactive Maps, Statistical Visualization, Transit Planning, Passenger Experience, Scalability

journal.title: GPS-Based Bus Stop Prediction Using Machine  Learning: A Data-Driven Approach for Smart  Urban Transit

meeting.title: GPS-Based Bus Stop Prediction Using Machine  Learning: A Data-Driven Approach for Smart  Urban Transit

data.title: GPS-Based Bus Stop Prediction Using Machine  Learning: A Data-Driven Approach for Smart  Urban Transit

metadata.title: Fraud Detection in Financial Services: Integrating Streaming Analytics and Machine Learning for Real-Time Threat Mitigation
metadata.description: Payment networks globally suffer relentless attacks from organized thieves who exploit weaknesses in aging bank security measures. Rule-based programs fail catastrophically when thieves change tactics faster than banks update detection formulas, while batch processing discovers theft long after money disappears. Banks now combine instant data streaming with smart computer programs that learn criminal patterns automatically. Apache Kafka and similar platforms move transaction information between systems in milliseconds, while mathematical models trained on millions of past fraud cases spot suspicious activity immediately. These intelligent programs examine dozens of factors simultaneously - purchase amounts, locations, timing, device fingerprints - discovering hidden connections that reveal organized theft rings. Every verified theft case feeds back into the software, helping computers recognize emerging attack methods without human intervention. Banks implementing these technologies report remarkable success: fraud catches jump dramatically while wrong alerts plummet, investigation costs drop through automation, and customers enjoy smoother payment experiences. Production systems operating across major banks demonstrate how combining lightning-fast data movement with continuously learning software builds unbreakable shields against financial theft. Moving from discovering empty accounts afterward to stopping thieves mid-transaction completely changes the game - criminal operations become difficult to run and unprofitable to maintain.

data.title: Fraud Detection in Financial Services: Integrating Streaming Analytics and Machine Learning for Real-Time Threat Mitigation

metadata.title: AI-Enhanced Seamless Handover in Wi-Fi Networks with Multi-Link Management
metadata.description: This work presents an innovative Multi-Parameter Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based decision algorithm, designed to optimize handovers in Wi-Fi networks supporting Multi-Link Operation (MLO). The algorithm employs a two-step Neural Network (NN) architecture to facilitate efficient handover processes, integrating a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) NN with a Classification NN. The former predicts key performance indicators, which are then used by the latter to determine the optimal connection between a Wi-Fi Station and available Access Points. Our approach, compared to traditional distance-based handover, effectively improves connectivity in more complex and realistic curvilinear trajectories.

meeting.title: 33rd International Conference on Software, Telecommunications, and Computer Networks

data.title: AI-Enhanced Seamless Handover in Wi-Fi Networks with Multi-Link Management

metadata.title: SIMULATION OF FILLER FLOCCULATION OF CLUSTERS OF PRIMARY PARTICLES
metadata.description:
Simulation of Filler Flocculation in Elastomers

This software is a three-dimensional simulation tool designed to visualize and understand a fundamental process in the material science of elastomer composites: filler flocculation. The program serves as a virtual laboratory to investigate how and why filler particles agglomerate in rubber-like materials. This process is crucial for the mechanical properties, durability, and performance of products such as car tires, seals, and vibration dampers.

Programmed with the use of AI Gemini 2.5 Pro.

creators.name: Stöckelhuber, Klaus Werner
creators.affiliation: Leibniz Institute of Polymer Research Dresden

keywords: Filler Flocculation, Elastomers, Schelling Segregation, NetLogo3D Software, Simulation

data.title: SIMULATION OF FILLER FLOCCULATION OF CLUSTERS OF PRIMARY PARTICLES

metadata.title: Time-Sensitive Networking for Trajectory Tracking of an Unmanned Ground Vehicle over Wi-Fi
metadata.description: In light of the evolving landscape of future converged networks, heightened demands for scalability and performance have become paramount, particularly in the industrial context where enhanced flexibility, adaptability, time synchronization and deterministic low latency are key features. Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN) has been introduced to provide converged networks with determinism. To mitigate the complexities associated with cabling requirements, Wireless Time-Sensitive Networking (WTSN) emerges as a more suited solution in industrial applications that need mobility. This study presents an application in smart manufacturing that incorporates WTSN technology. Specifically, it focuses on a scenario where an Unmanned Ground Vehicle (UGV), under the control of an edge controller connected through a wireless link, operates within a critical environment subject to constraints such as to avoid obstacles and to build a real-time map of the surrounding area. The mapping outcome performed by the edge controller demonstrates the effectiveness of the WTSN capabilities.

meeting.title: 2024 IEEE 29th International Conference on Emerging Technologies and Factory Automation

data.title: Time-Sensitive Networking for Trajectory Tracking of an Unmanned Ground Vehicle over Wi-Fi

metadata.title: E2E DetNet Configurator - IETF Hackaton 2025
metadata.description:
This repository includes a modular end-to-end configuration system for Deterministic Networking (DetNet).
It accepts service requests, computes latency-/bandwidth-constrained paths, reserves resources, and pushes configurations to network devices — all with optional simulation and watchdog support.

This information can also be found in the next link, please check it for updates:  PREDICT 6G / IETF Hackaton - GitLab (uc3m.es)

This work has been funded by the European Commission Horizon Europe SNS JU PREDICT-6G (GA 101095890) Project.

metadata.title: The Role of Machine Learning to Predict Potentially Toxic Elements Remobilisation and Bioaccessibility Change During Flooding
metadata.description:
Abstract

Climate change and urbanisation have exacerbated flooding in many regions. Flooding alters soil hydrochemical properties (e.g., pH), affecting the mobility and bioaccessibility of potentially toxic elements such as lead, which are harmful to humans and ecosystems. Accurately modelling the hydrochemical processes driving these changes remains poorly understood. This study compares machine learning with statistical models to predict changes in hydrochemical processes influencing mobility and bioaccessibility. Soil samples from two distinct catchments, the Clyde and Humber, were analysed under varying pre-and-post-flooding simulation patterns or regimes. Random forest, XGBoost, and neural network models, alongside a statistical mixed model, were trained using soil porewater hydrochemistry data from the Clyde to predict mobility and bioaccessibility in the Humber. We revealed four distinct hydrochemical phases  - first lag, critical, subcritical, and second lag - characterising shifts during flooding. The critical phase (days 2-4) showed the most significant change, and focusing training during this period significantly improved model performance. Machine learning variable importance revealed manganese, redox potential, pH, and iron as key drivers influencing mobility. Random forest achieved the highest predictive accuracy (R2 > 0.70) for estimating mobility and bioaccessibility, outperforming the other models and successfully generalising to the Humber.

data.title: The Role of Machine Learning to Predict Potentially Toxic Elements Remobilisation and Bioaccessibility Change During Flooding

metadata.title: CAM SCM simulations for the KWAJEX field campaign
metadata.description:
We conduct KWAJEX simulations using the single-column version of the Community Atmospheric Model (CAM) with a hierarchy of parameterization schemes for PBL turbulence and cumulus convection, spanning from traditional standalone schemes (CAM_ZMUW) to unified convection schemes (CAM_UNICON), unified cloud–turbulence representations (CAM_CLUBB), and super parameterizations (CAM_SP). Details of these four distinct configurations are as follows: 

kwjx_4scam KWAJEX forcings
crm_kwjx cloud-resolving model (CRM) outputs
scam_kwjx_zmuw

Deep convection: Zhang & McFarlane (1995) scheme

PBL turbulence and shallow convection: Park & Bretherton (2009) scheme
scam_kwjx_unicon

Shallow and deep convection: a unified framework (Park, 2014a)

PBL turbulence: Bretherton and Park (2009)
scam_kwjx_clubb Cloud Layers Unified by Binormals (CLUBB) scheme (Golaz et al., 2002; Guo et al., 2021), which is further extended to replace the Zhang-McFarlane deep convection scheme
scam_kwjx_sp CRM with kilometer-scale resolution embedded in each grid column of the host CAM 
scam_kwjx_clubb_silhs CLUBB with the stochastic Subgrid Importance Latin Hypercube Sampler (SILHS)
scam_kwjx_clubb_zm CLUBB with the Zhang-McFarlane convection scheme

data.title: CAM SCM simulations for the KWAJEX field campaign
